_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary
New York City Environmental Protection (NYCDEP) uses chlorine to meet the New York State Sanitary Code and federal Safe Drinking Water Act disinfection requirements.  Kensico is one of the locations where some of the City's water is treated with chlorine.
NYCDEP is committed to protecting the public, its employees, and the environment from any accidental releases of hazardous materials used at its facilities.  We have implemented safety, environmental protection, and risk management programs to prevent hazardous materials releases. 
If there is an accidental release, we will immediately notify the DEP Police Eastview Precinct to mobilize DEP's emergency response team and the local emergency responders to minimize the effect of the release and notify the public of any actions necessary to ensure public protection, through county emergency management agencies.
Accidental Release Prevention Steps
NYCDEP is committed to public safety, personnel safety, continued reliable operation and regulatory compliance.  Based on this commitment, an individual, designated as the RMP Responsible Manager, has assumed overall responsibility for the implementation of the Risk Management Program.  The RMP Responsible Manager has also clearly defined accountability and responsibility for each of the prevention program elements to meet both EPA and OSHA Process Safety Management requirements.
To ensure that an offsite release scenario does not occur, the NYCDEP maintains a release prevention program with the primary focus of protecting the public and plant employees from the hazards associated with an accident or release involving chlorine. 
 The multifaceted program includes the use of:
	- Chlorine detectors and alarms to rapidly alert operators to any problems;
        - Personal chlorine monitors to continuously monitor concentrations in the employee's 
           breathing zone;
	- Process Safety Information to document the safe process design;
	- Process Hazards Anal

yses to evaluate the chemical and process hazards;
	- Operating Procedures to ensure that the system is operated safely;
	- Maintenance, inspection and testing to ensure that the system is maintained according to 
           applicable standards and manufacturer's recommendations.
	- Training, hot work permits, contractor safety and employee participation programs to 
           ensure that all employees and contractors working on and around the processes are aware 
           of the hazards, can perform their job duties safely and know the actions to be taken in an 
           emergency;
	- Management of Change and Pre-startup Safety Reviews to ensure that changes are 
           documented, analyzed and kept within the design basis;
	- Incident Investigation procedure to investigate each incident and "near misses" to 
           determine root causes and make needed safety improvements; and,
	- Periodic compliance audits to ensure that our programs are working as they should to 
           protect both the public and employees.
Five-Year Accident History
Within the past five years, the Kensico Facility has not had accidental releases that resulted in injuries or property damage. The plant has maintained an excellent safety record throughout its operating history.  
Emergency Response
In the event that a chlorine release does occur, the Kensico Facility has an Emergency Response Team (ERT) that coordinates emergency response with the Fire Department and other local emergency responders. If such a release did occur, plant personnel would contact the DEP Police Eastview Precinct who would notify 60 Control and the Mount Pleasant Police Department call centers. The call centers would dispatch outside responders to the site to address the chlorine release. The Eastview Precinct Command Center would also notify DEP Operations and ERT to support the emergency response.
Maintaining Safe Operation
The NYCDEP continually works to safely manage the hazards of chlorine to pro

tect the employees and community we serve. The Risk Management Program is maintained to reduce the risk of accidental releases. Each year we conduct training, review procedures, maintain the equipment and follow safe work practices. Periodically, we audit our program, review our Process Hazard Analysis and coordinate with the community emergency response organization. A chlorine system emergency scrubber system is installed to further reduce and minimize the likelihood of an off-site consequence. As indicated in the Alternative Release Scenario 1 the most likely scenario for any cause of a release the emergency scrubber captures and absorb all the material and emits less than 5 ppm in the stack. Modeling indicates that there are no ground level concentrations above the EPA criterion, but minimum values are entered based on RMP*Submit limitations. Note that the area close to the facility has flat or Rural topography, but this transitions to a rough surface or Urban topography for the greater distance of the Worst-Case Scenario.  Expansion pots and relief valves are in place to further increase safety related to a potential chlorine system incident. In addition, automatic shutoff valves are provided throughout the systems and are interlocked with the sensors and alarms to shut down the operations in the event of a chlorine.
